clinical_study.brief_title: A Biosensor for Tracking Seizures: Linking a Wrist Accelerometer to an Online Epilepsy Diary
clinical_study.official_title: A Biosensor for Tracking Seizures: Linking a Wrist Accelerometer to an Online Epilepsy Diary

brief_summary.textblock: This study will assess whether a movement detecting wristwatch can accurately detect seizures and seizure characteristics and record them into an online epilepsy diary. The patients may manually record a description into the online epilepsy diary of the symptoms they experienced before, during or after the seizure.

detailed_description.textblock: Typically, health care providers receive inaccurate patient self- reports. This pilot trial will document the feasibility of accurately recording and logging seizures into a cloud-based diary, under circumstances of controlled video-EEG monitoring to serve as a comparison "gold standard." More explicitly, we are testing the efficacy of the wristwatch in capturing movement parameters correlated with seizure activity and whether these parameters can be accurately uploaded into an online epilepsy diary. In the future, biosensor data could be valuable to more precisely obtain seizure data for clinical decision making as well as use in clinical trials.

primary_outcome.measure: Capture rate of convulsive seizure events by the watch and watch-diary interface compared to video electroencephalography (vEEG)

secondary_outcome.measure: Capture rate of non-seizure events by the watch and watch-diary interface compared to vEEG
Frequency of movements of the watch diary interface vs vEEG
Amplitude of movements of the watch diary interface vs vEEG
Seizure semiology captured by the watch vs vEEG.
Specificity of audio recordings of the watch vs vEEG
secondary_outcome.description: Will record audio through the watch and vEEG to assess the specificity of this parameter for epileptic vs nonepileptic seizures

other_outcome.measure: Recording accuracy of convulsive seizure events by the watch and watch-diary interface compared to vEEG
other_outcome.description: Will measure the date and time, duration and shake intensity of convulsive seizure events by the watch and watch-diary interface compared to vEEG
Will survey whether the device was easy, neutral, difficult to use
Will compare partial seizure events detected by vEEG vs. watch-diary vs. patient log vs. caregiver log

study_pop.textblock: Adults with epilepsy over the age of 18 enrolled at the Stanford Epilepsy Monitoring Unit.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
-Adults over the age of 18 with known epileptic convulsive seizures already being admitted to the EMU for continuous video EEG.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with only non-convulsive events or only psychogenic non-epileptic seizures.
- Patients who are unable to provide consent.
- Patients who have developmental delay.
